data.text: Contents
Introduction

This document sets out the procedure for dealing with disciplinary matters within the Trust and applies to all staff within the Trust. Its purpose is to ensure that disciplinary matters are dealt with fairly and reasonably. This policy complies with the ACAS Code of Practice on Disciplinary and Grievances Policies and Procedures (March 2015). The Trust is committed to the effective management of conduct at work to ensure the efficient provision of services and the safety and well-being of Staff and the general public.
The aim of the Disciplinary Policy is to:
Set clear standards of behaviour at work and the disciplinary rules (refer to Appendix 1);
Emphasise that disciplinary issues should be approached constructively, wherever possible, with the aim of helping the member of staff to change their behaviour;
Prevent the member of staff from breaking a rule again, rather than merely punishing them;
To ensure consistency, fairness and transparency.
Scope

This policy and its associated procedures will apply to all staff directly employed by the Trust regardless of length of service unless specified by their terms and conditions of service, e.g. bank staff (other than when specific conditions may apply e.g. Medical staff and dentists). This also includes trainees, secondees and staff on honorary contracts or on joint contracts with the Trust and another employer including students.

Concerns about the conduct or competence of medical staff and dentists, will initially be dealt with in conjunction with the document Maintaining High Professional Standards in the Modern NHS (MHPS), a framework for the handling of concerns about doctors and dentists in the NHS. Where that process concludes that there is a case of misconduct that should be put to a disciplinary panel, a hearing will be convened and conducted in accordance with this policy taking account of any requirements set out in MHPS.

It is recognised that the various professional bodies, of which many health care staff are required to have membership, will also have professional standards of capability, conduct and competence. The Trust requires Staff in those professions to adhere to those standards.

Cases of misconduct perpetrated outside of work by staff may also be managed through this policy. The circumstances should be considered on their merits, the managers must give careful consideration as to whether an individual's role and/or the reputation of the Trust have been unduly affected as a result of the act of misconduct.
Definitions

table_items.text: Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust
Maintaining High Professional Standards in the Modern NHS

Misconduct is defined as failure in personal conduct .A complaint is received, or matters come to light that require investigation. This could be an alleged matter relating to conduct outside employment

Gross misconduct is defined as misconduct serious enough to compromise the employment contract between the Trust and the staff/worker which makes further working relationship and Trust impossible. Gross misconduct is normally restricted to serious offences.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Staff

Staff currently subjected to any management investigation or associated disciplinary process are expected to cooperate fully at each stage of the process and the terms of the disciplinary action is to bring to resolution as quickly as possible.

Staff who are witnesses for any management investigation or associated formal processes should cooperate fully with the investigation, and attend a hearing as a witness if they are requested to do so, unless there are exceptional circumstances that have been discussed with the Employee Relations Team.

Should staff fail to co-operate with disciplinary matters this may be deemed a disciplinary offence in its own right. Further information can be sought from the Employee Relations Team should this situation arise.
Staff must familiarise themselves with the Trust and individual Trust's policies and procedures to ensure they understand the Trust's expectations.

Staff are expected to raise concerns if they believe that other members of staff's behaviour contravenes the Trust's expectation and boundaries, especially if it may impact on patient or staff safety or wellbeing.
Manager

Managers must monitor and manage the conduct of Staff and be clear about expected standards of behaviour. Where conduct issues start to emerge, the Manager must ensure that the individual is made aware at the earliest opportunity to allow them to correct their behaviour.
Managers must be aware of the Trust's policies and procedures and how to use them to manage issues that arise whilst ensuring fairness and consistency across their service and the Trust.

Managers should ensure that they have attended and received adequate training in the role that they are appointed to within the management of the case. Managers should seek advice from the relevant advisors taking into account their own level of capability and experience.
Managers should ensure that they are applying policy consistently and in a way that is sensitive to equality and diversity.

It is a fundamental management responsibility to take disciplinary action when it becomes appropriate. Managers have an obligation to investigate complaints or allegations received concerning staff where their conduct is called into question.

Managers have a responsibility to ensure appropriate management of Staff following a disciplinary issue, and for implementing any actions/recommendations arising from the disciplinary process, whilst keeping the member of staff informed of progress.
Trade Union Representative

Where the member of staff is a trade union member, the expectation will be that the trade union representative will support the staff member and ensure they are able to attend any relevant meeting in a timely manner and cooperate with the Trust policies and processes. In normal circumstances the Trust will deal directly with the member of staff on all matters, and only by mutual agreement will the Trust deal directly with the Trade union representative.
Employee Relations Team
The Employee Relations Team has a role and responsibility in ensuring that the policy is developed and implemented across the Trust fairly and consistently.

The Employee Relations Team  will give guidance on any matter relating to the interpretation of the policy and procedure and advice should be sought in cases considered to merit formal disciplinary action, suspension from duty or dismissal.
The primary role of a member of the Employee Relations Team will be to share their specialist knowledge of procedural issues, relevant Trust policies and employment law matters.
Commissioning Manager

This is normally the line manager or another appropriate manager. The Commissioning Manager (Case Manager MHPS) role is to review the case and where necessary commission an investigation into concerns of conduct in accordance with the Trust's Investigation Policy. Upon receiving the investigation report, the Commissioning Manager will review the findings, and then be the decision maker for any next steps including whether a hearing should be convened.

It is the Commissioning Manager's responsibility to ensure that all processes are completed in a timely and effective way, and to ensure that the member of staff is not subject to unfair treatment as a result of the process.
It is also the responsibility of the Commissioning Manager to communicate with the member of staff to keep them informed throughout the process (both verbally and in writing).
Investigating Officer

A member of Staff, trained in carrying out management investigations appointed by the Commissioning Manager to carry out an investigation into an issue, allegation or event in accordance with the Trust's MSEPO-20221 Workforce Investigations Policy. Refer to the Trust's MSEPO-20221 Workforce Investigation Policy for further information.
Panel Chair
The Chair of the Panel will normally be the Commissioning Manager and must have the authority to agree the outcome and with the authority to dismiss, if required.
The Chair of the Panel is responsible for ensuring the hearing is conducted in a fair manner and all parties are permitted to state their case appropriately and professionally.

The Chair of the Panel must agree the outcome and have the appropriate authority. The reasons for outcome decisions must be clearly documented. The Chair of the Panel is also responsible for informing the member of staff of the outcome and their right to appeal.
Equality and Diversity

The Trust is committed to embracing the Equality Act 2010 in all its employment practices and strives to eliminate all unfair discrimination, harassment, bullying and victimisation. Equality of opportunity is a high priority within the Trust and will not unlawfully, unfairly or unreasonably discriminate or treat individuals less favourably on the grounds of gender, marital status, sexual orientation, pregnancy or maternity leave, religion or belief, disability, age, race, nationality or ethnic origin.

Reasonable adjustments will be made for Staff who deem themselves to have a disability or accessibility issues, as appropriate to individual circumstances, to ensure proper participation in disciplinary processes.
Authority to Take Disciplinary Action
The authority to take disciplinary action (including issuing of sanctions) against a member of staff up to and including dismissal is outlined in Appendix
Governing and Statutory Bodies

Where concerns about an staff member's professional misconduct or fitness to practice, including concerns about a practitioner's health, are serious enough to affect a practitioner's registration, the Trust may be obliged to refer the matter to the relevant professional body. This referral will usually be undertaken by the Trust's professional lead, namely the Chief Nurse or the Chief Medical Officer. Refer to the Professional Registrations Policy for further information.

Where the alleged misconduct poses a risk to a vulnerable adult or child (as defined by the Safeguarding Authority) the relevant Vulnerable Adult Protection Co-ordinator or the Named Nurse for Child Protection should be consulted as soon as possible.

If fraudulent activity is suspected advice should be sought from the Employee Relations Team and / or the Local Counter Fraud Specialist (LCFS). Any evidence obtained should be retained. The alleged perpetrator should not be made aware of such suspicions due to the potential for the destruction of evidence until the Employee Relations Team and the LCFS confirm the action to be taken.

Where an investigation establishes a suspected criminal action in the UK or abroad, this will be reported to the Police by the Commissioning Manager. The Trust has the discretion to proceed with its own investigation and disciplinary action in accordance with this procedure, without awaiting the outcome of any police investigation or prosecution in so far as this does not impede with any criminal investigation. Advice should be sought in this instance by the Employee Relations Team.
Staff Support

The Trust recognises that Staff may find this process difficult and it is therefore important that Staff are informed of support mechanisms available e.g. Occupational Health, access to the Trust's Employee Assistance Programme. Basildon and Southend service is provided by CiC; telephone number 0800 085 1376 / 020 79380963; email assist@cic-eap.co.uk/ or Mid Essex in house Psychological Therapy Service 01245 514838.
Process Overview
Informal Process

On most occasions, it will not be appropriate for managers to use the formal disciplinary procedure on the first occasion of poor conduct by a member of staff. Cases of minor misconduct e.g. lateness, should be dealt with by the line manager initially via an informal discussion with the individual.
The purpose of an informal discussion between the manager and the individual is to:
Establish the basic facts from both perspectives: The circumstance of misconduct is explained to the member of staff; the member of staff explains their perspective, the manager listens;
Explore matters of concern: Both parties ask questions to clarify their perspectives and seek information about any underlying or contributing issues
Clarify the behaviours/conduct required for the future: The manager outlines the behaviours expected and the staff member has a chance to explore any gaps in understanding.
The manager must then establish the next steps:
The manager outlines the next steps to be taken having listened to their perspective and may include (but not restricted to):
Agreeing that the misconduct will not happen again and confirming the consequences should it do so;
Identifying opportunities for development and/or learning and support available to help the member of staff meet the required standard of conduct;
Take no action given the circumstances presented by the member of staff.

Any outcomes and/or action plans should be followed up in writing by the line manager to ensure expectations of standards of behaviour/conduct in the future are clear and action that will be taken if a similar concern/misconduct occurs.
Where informal discussion fails to address the issue, it will be appropriate to follow the formal disciplinary procedure outlined below.
Whilst, at the informal stage, there is no right to representation for the member of staff, the line manager may wish to consider their involvement in exceptional
circumstances to facilitate an open and honest dialogue. This should not however be allowed to unnecessarily delay the informal process.

Care should be taken to identify whether concerns raised about a member of staff's behaviour are related to conduct or capability. If the concern is related to capability the Performance Improvement Policy should be followed.

There are some circumstances where it is not appropriate for matters to be dealt with informally. An example would be serious acts of misconduct, which may progress straight to the formal stages, for more detail of examples of misconduct and gross misconduct see Appendix
Initial Fact Finding

Where an incident or concern comes to light, the manager will need to consider whether an initial fact finding is warranted in order to decide whether to proceed to a formal investigation, or if the facts of the matter are clear and established. The Employee Relations Team should be contacted for advice as necessary.

The initial fact finding requires either the manager or the most senior person on duty at the time of the incident, to undertake some initial one to one enquires and make a note of the findings – e.g. what happened, when did it happen, who saw or was involved in the incident(s) in question and what was done as a result.
Having spoken to the staff member and the key witness (es), the manager, will need to come to a conclusion as to whether a more full and thorough investigation is necessary.
The purpose of initial fact finding is to ensure that staff are not subject to an unnecessary process where there is little point in undertaking a formal investigation
Formal Process
The formal stages of the procedure apply where the manager has reasonable grounds to consider:
There has been no improvement in the individuals conduct following an agreement at the informal stage;
Agreement about the required change in behaviour cannot be achieved informally;
The individual's alleged misconduct is such that formal action is considered unavoidable.
Ways to Manage Risks

When there are any risks associated with staff continuing in their role whilst a formal disciplinary process is undertaken, the Commissioning Manager/Case Manager must consider whether it is necessary to place temporary restrictions on their practice. This might be to amend or restrict the Staff duties, or provide for the suspension of the member of staff from the workplace. Any considerations, decisions or outcomes relating to this will need to be documented in the Suspension Assessment (refer to Appendix 3)
Options to consider to the manage risk:
Close supervision of normal duties;
Restricting the member of staff to certain forms of duties;
Restricting activities to administrative, research/audit, teaching and other educational duties. By mutual agreement the latter might include some formal retraining or re-skilling;
Temporary redeployment;
Suspension.
Suspension from Duty
The MSE Trust does not underestimate the impact of suspension and will always consider alternatives as above where possible.

The MSE Trust will give full consideration to the suitability of suspension and this will normally only be used in cases which involve potential serious misconduct and/or when the Staff continued presence could interfere with or compromise the investigation. Where it is within the power of the Trust, individuals will suffer no detriment as a result of being suspended. Suspension should be rarely exercised, and should be for the shortest possible period. Alternatives to suspension should
always be considered where this would serve to remove the need for, replace or shorten a period of suspension.

Under normal circumstances, prior to a decision being made to suspend staff, managers must consult with the Employee Relations Team to ensure that suspension is appropriate and that there is consistency throughout the Trust. However, in exceptional circumstances, for example, out of normal office hours, this may not be possible. In these circumstances the manager concerned must contact the Employee Relations Team at the earliest opportunity to review the decision to suspend.

Suspension is a ‘neutral act', that is to say it is a precautionary measure and not itself considered as disciplinary action, nor does it presume guilt and is therefore on contractual pay, (other than in exceptional circumstances e.g. when a member of staff is in half-pay/no pay on sickness absence or on an unpaid sabbatical, or some other substantial reason, such as no right to work, lapse in professional registration, bank staff and some criminal proceedings).
The suspension may be carried out at any stage but should be for no longer than is reasonably necessary to carry out the investigation and arrange a hearing.

The Commissioning Manager/Case Manager will review suspensions and exclusions every 2 weeks and in accordance with MHPS after 4 weeks, to ascertain the current status of the investigation and the predicted future time scale for review. The Manager will consider whether the reason for suspension still applies and notify the member of staff accordingly.
The full process and rules of suspension are detailed in Appendix  Agreed Outcome
An agreed outcome is the process in which an outcome of a disciplinary proceeding can be agreed without the need for a disciplinary hearing.
It is recognised that lengthy disciplinary proceedings can create anxiety for all those involved in the process and additional pressure on service delivery.

Following initial fact finding in relation to the specific incident including the recognition of the member of staff, the Trust may deem it appropriate to engage in an agreed outcome process. The Trust will write to the member of staff giving 7 calendar days' notice to attend the meeting. The letter will include the allegation(s), the right to be accompanied and all appropriate details.
The relevant Manager with the authority to issue disciplinary sanctions will be in attendance and decide the level of proposed sanction for the member of staff for an agreed outcome.
At the meeting all parties (staff, representative and appropriate authorised manager) will be present, together with a member of the Employee Relations
Team. At the meeting, all information relevant to the allegation(s) must be available and all parties will have the opportunity to discuss all necessary issues.

Agreed outcomes are only appropriate where both parties are agreeable to the process. If either the member of staff or their representative is unhappy with a proposal of an agreed outcome, then the normal disciplinary process must be followed. At this stage, the decision to proceed to a formal hearing must be referred to the Head of Employee Relations, who will convene a Fair Treatment Panel.

The Trust can propose a suitable sanction without recourse to a disciplinary hearing. The member of staff, in consultation with their representative, can accept or decline the sanction. If the sanction is accepted, there is no right to appeal. In this process, a sanction short of dismissal may be imposed. If the member of staff wishes to proceed, a letter of acceptance should be signed and returned to their manager within 7 calendar days. If the member of staff decides against the agreed outcome during this time, or does not return the letter of acceptance, the normal disciplinary process will continue.
Any disciplinary sanction issued in this way has the same status as one issued at a disciplinary hearing.

In an agreed outcome meeting – only information relevant to the incident can be discussed – this is not an opportunity to introduce other issues/concerns that pre- date the incident and should be managed in the usual way; or introduce other issues that have already been addressed both informally and formally.
It is not appropriate to use the agreed outcome process in cases of gross misconduct.
Investigation
All investigations should be conducted in accordance with the MSE Investigation Policy.
Overlapping Disciplinary and Grievance Cases

Where staff raise a grievance during the disciplinary process, the Trust will consider whether the disciplinary process may be temporarily adjourned in order to deal with the grievance. Where the grievance and disciplinary cases are related, it may be appropriate to deal with both issues concurrently.
Fair Treatment Panel

If the Commissioning Manager believes that formal action is required e.g. invoking a formal procedure, then this decision must be referred to a Fair Treatment Panel which will consist of the Head of Employee Relations or a Deputy, a Site Associate Director for HR and where appropriate a senior clinical or operational lead. The panel will review the investigation for equity and any

formal action for parity and fairness. The panel will either confirm the formal action or make alternate recommendations. If the decision to proceed to a hearing is confirmed, the hearing should be arranged within 10 calendar days of notification of the panel decision.
Disciplinary Hearing

Should a Hearing be deemed necessary, the member of staff must be informed in writing of the substance of the case against them and advised of their right to representation at the hearing at least 10 calendar days before the hearing unless mutually agreed otherwise by both parties. All documentation and evidence relevant to the hearing must be provided to the member of staff with the written notification. The member of staff should be informed in the notification that the outcome of the hearing could include formal disciplinary action taken against them and what the maximum sanction could be. If the potential outcome could include dismissal, this should be clearly stated.

Names of witnesses on both sides must be exchanged  calendar days in advance of the hearing. It is up to the member of staff to ensure that any witnesses they are calling in support of their case have been told when and where the hearing is taking place and that they are available. Unavailability cannot delay proceedings.

At least 5 calendar days before the hearing the member of staff will be required to submit any written statement or documentation that they want to refer to at the hearing. Except in exceptional circumstances, they will not be able to submit anything later or during the proceedings. This is to allow the Hearing Chair sufficient time to review this documentation in order to give a fair hearing.

If the member of staff or their representative/work colleague are unable to attend the disciplinary hearing as arranged it may, depending on the circumstances, may be rearranged. In these circumstances all reasonable steps will be taken to agree a mutually convenient time and date. If the member of staff unreasonably fails to attend the agreed reconvened hearing, the Hearing Chair may decide to hear the case in their absence and the decision will be based on the information available to them at the time of the Hearing. Only one rearrangement will be permitted. In such cases it will also be possible for the Chair of the hearing to accept for consideration a written statement from either the member of staff or their representative.
Outcome of the Disciplinary Hearing

The  decision  of  the  panel  conducting  the hearing  will  normally  be  given  to member of staff verbally at the end of the hearing. However, the Chair of the hearing may feel additional time is needed to make a decision and the member of staff will then either be informed in writing or the hearing reconvened for the decision to be given verbally. In all cases, the decision will be confirmed in
writing to the member of staff within 7 calendar days of the hearing, unless extended timescales are agreed.

A decision to issue a disciplinary sanction should be based on evidence available at the time of the hearing and the standard of proof whether the allegations are proven on the balance of probabilities.
Possible conclusions are that there has been:
No case to answer: No action to be taken and all references to it will be removed from the Staff personal file;

Further investigation required: This is where the panel feels that it requires further evidence to be obtained before making a final decision. The hearing would be adjourned and reconvened when the additional information can be considered and a final outcome reached;
Misconduct, but not serious enough to warrant formal disciplinary action. Informal action may be taken in accordance with section 9;
Misconduct which is considered to be sufficiently serious to warrant formal disciplinary action up to and including dismissal.
Formal Disciplinary Action
Where it is decided that the misconduct warrants formal disciplinary action the below options should be considered.

Where formal action applies the outcome letter will set out the reason for the disciplinary action and will confirm what the next steps would be if there is no satisfactory improvement and/or further repetition of misconduct. This will also set out the right to appeal in line with the Trust Appeal Policy.

A copy of the outcome letter detailing the disciplinary action will be held on the personnel file but subject to achieving and sustaining satisfactory conduct will normally be considered spent after the expiry of the warning.
First Written Warning

This is normally appropriate for cases where there has been a failure to improve following previous management advice or it is a sufficiently serious first offence which may warrant an immediate first written warning.
Duration of warnings is in line with section 11.14.
Final Written Warning
Final Warnings may be given if:
The member of staff is subject to a first written warning and has failed to respond to the required standard within the defined period or;
If it is a sufficiently serious first offence which may warrant an immediate final written warning.
The member of staff must be advised that no satisfactory improvement and/or further repetition of misconduct could result in dismissal.
Duration of warnings is in line with section 11.17.
Action Short of Dismissal

There may be exceptional circumstances where the Trust takes the view that whilst dismissal may be warranted, organisational and member of staff circumstance may best be served by action short of dismissal itself. In these circumstances, one of the following sanctions may be considered as an alternative to dismissal only. These sanctions will normally be applied on a substantive basis. If the member of staff does not agree with this course of action, dismissal will result.
Demotion without pay protection;
Transfer to another post at the same or alternative grade/band within the organisation – without pay protection (for example enhancements) or excess mileage payments.

The member of staff would be appointed on the terms and conditions appropriate to the role. As this is an alternative to summary dismissal they would not be given notice and would be issued with a new contract of employment.

The Trust cannot create posts to accommodate demotions or transfers and consideration of such a course of action will only be possible where a vacancy exists. Any of the above sanctions will be accompanied by a final written warning which will remain on the personnel file for up to  months.
Dismissal
A member of staff may be under consideration for dismissal if:
It  is established  that  there is  a  breach  of discipline  after  a  final  written warning, unless there are exceptional mitigating circumstances, or
On the balance of probability it is believed that they have committed gross misconduct in accordance with the disciplinary rules.
(Refer to Appendix 1).
If following the disciplinary hearing it is decided that dismissal should take place, the member of staff must be informed in writing of the following:
The reason for the dismissal, with reference to any previous warnings;
The type of dismissal, with notice or summary dismissal without notice;

Where the reason for dismissal is gross misconduct the dismissal will be summary i.e. without notice. Where the dismissal is not for reason of gross misconduct the Trust, at its discretion, can either give notice of termination or make pay in lieu of notice;
The effective date of dismissal;
The right of appeal against dismissal.
The Chair of the Panel will send formal confirmation of the dismissal and right of appeal within 7 calendar days of the Hearing.
Types of dismissal

Dismissal with contractual notice: Generally associated with dismissals due to misconduct where prior warnings have been given. The member of staff will be required to leave the workplace immediately and will be paid in lieu of notice along with any other monies they may be entitled to e.g. accrual of annual leave entitlement

Summary  dismissal  without  notice:  Only  applicable  in  relation  to  dismissals associated  with  acts  of  gross  misconduct  and  therefore  serious  enough  to dismiss without prior warning. Examples of misconduct are included in appendix

1. Payment will cease immediately and no payment in lieu of notice will be made. The member of staff will be required to leave the premises immediately and make arrangements to return property including ID badge/Keys/IT and telephone equipment.
Length of Warnings

Disciplinary warnings remain ‘active' for a stipulated period of time but will expire after  that,  provided  the  required  standard  of  performance  or  conduct  is maintained. The standard period of time a sanction may be issued for is as follows:
First written warning  up to  months Final written warning  up to  months

In exceptional cases, including in particular cases of gross misconduct, as an alternative to dismissal, the Trust may extend the duration of the written warnings, subject to the right to appeal against the sanction and imposition of any extended period for e.g. cases relating to abuse or negligence towards patients, fellow Staff or the general public etc.
Spent warnings will usually be disregarded for any future disciplinary purpose.

Details will not automatically be physically removed from the member of staffs personnel file. If the member of staff would prefer that details be physically removed, they should request the physical removal of the warning by their line manager or supervisor once the warning has expired. However, this does not negate employment history.
Representation

A member of staff who is the subject of disciplinary investigation has the statutory right to be accompanied by a Trade Union Representative or their choice or a work place colleague at a disciplinary hearing.

The Trust extends the statutory right for staff who are the subject of an investigation, to be accompanied at investigation meetings. This right does not extend to witnesses participating in the investigation.

The work colleague/trade union representative has a statutory right to address any formal meeting but no statutory right to answer questions on the member of staff's behalf. They will also be permitted reasonable time to confer privately with the member of staff and to ask questions on their behalf.

The Trust's relationship and communication is directly with its Staff. On this basis, it is the responsibility of the member of staff concerned to arrange for a representative or work colleague to be available to attend and to provide them with all relevant information and documentation.
Staff will not be permitted to bring a Solicitor or be represented by anyone acting in a professional legal capacity
Confidentiality

All proceedings, witness statements, and records will be kept confidential. However, in exceptional cases, there may be circumstances in which disclosure is desirable, but only with the agreement of the member of staff and management. There may be occasions where the Trust has an obligation to refer information to professional and legal bodies and the police. Further information for staff on confidentiality issues can be provided on request.
Appeals Procedure
The right of appeal is in accordance with the Trusts Appeal Policy.
Referrals to the Disclosure and Barring Service
Referrals under this procedure to the Disclosure and Barring Service will be made in accordance with the Disclosure and Barring Service Referral Guide.
Training Requirements
This policy is in immediate effect from its agreement date. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the Employee Relations Team.
Monitoring and Audit
The policy will be monitored annually by the Employee Relations Team with areas of exception being highlighted.
A yearly audit of all formal disciplinary cases will be carried out.

This policy has been reviewed and approved by the Employee Relations team and will be implemented with immediate effect from its agreement date. This document will be available electronically on the Trust Intranets. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the Employee Relations Team.

ACAS  Code  of  Practice  on  Grievance  and  Disciplinary  Policies  and Procedures 2015

Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix 4)
The Trust aim to design and implement services, policies, procedures, needs of our  service,  population  and  workforce,  ensuring  that  none  are  placed  at  a disadvantage over others.

In order to meet these requirements, an equality impact assessment is used to assess all its policies, procedures and practices. This procedure was found to be compliant with this assessment. (Refer to Appendix 4)
Appendix 1: Misconduct and Gross Misconduct
Types of Misconduct
Examples of types of offence that may be regarded as misconduct:
Minor breaches of Trust rules and procedures.
Any behaviour inconsistent with the Staff Charter/Trust values.
Failure to follow procedures.
Poor time-keeping and attendance.
Persistent or unauthorised or unreasonable absence.
Breaches of Health & Safety legislation.
Poor productivity and/or unsatisfactory standard of work.
Inappropriate dress or appearance
Offensive, abusive or objectionable behaviour.
Posting or distributing material which may be construed as offensive.
Posting or distributing unauthorised literature.
Misuse or abuse of Trust premises or property.
Misuse of Trust systems e.g. e-mail/internet/intranet/PAS.
Failure to follow reasonable instructions.
Unsatisfactory performance attributable to indiscipline.
Breach of confidentiality.
Engaging in activities on or off the premises which could be considered to be a discredit to the Trust or its Staff.
Undertaking additional employment which would counter the interests of the Trust or would conflict with the member of staff's own position. Smoking in designated no smoking areas.
This list takes into account the main categories of misconduct: the list cannot however be considered exhaustive.
Types of Gross Misconduct

The  following  offences  are  regarded  as  very  serious  and  will  be  treated as  Gross Misconduct. If an individual is found to have committed one of these offences they could be dismissed without notice.
Inappropriate use of social media that may bring the Trust into disrepute.
Acts of violence, intimidation, assault, disorderly behaviour or other behaviours that are inconsistent with the Trust values.

Theft, attempted theft, fraud or forgery: Any instance of theft or attempted theft from the Trust, or from patients/clients, visitors, or other members of staff. Trust property must not be removed from the Trust premises for personal use, nor used for private purposes within the premises without prior written approval of the member of staff's manager. Property issued for personal use in Trust residential accommodation must not be removed from there.
Engaging in secondary employment during hours when contracted to work for the Trust or during periods of designated leave, for example sickness absence or time for training etc.

Deliberate falsification of records or documents, e.g. employment application, timesheets, rostering data, expense claims, abuse of sick pay etc. Any deliberate attempt to get money or goods through falsification of any records or documents that relate to employment from the Trust or members of the public in the course of official duties.
Wilful damage to, or unauthorised possession of, Trust property belonging to another member of staff, patient or visitor, particularly anything provided for Health and Safety or the Trust premises.

Any serious breach of professional boundaries with patients. Staff are also not permitted to enter into financial transactions with patients/clients or their relatives relating to goods or property, which could be to the pecuniary advantage of the member of staff.
Serious misuse of Trust systems, e.g. e-mail system/internet/intranet/PAS.
Deliberately accessing internet sites containing inappropriate material.

Refusal to comply with, deliberate disregard of, or a serious breach of Health and Safety rules, a serious failure to co-operate under the terms of the Health and Safety at Work Act or regulations made there under.
Gross negligence or incompetence – any action or failure to act, which threatens the health or safety of a patient/client, visitor, member of the public or another member of staff.
Persistent refusal to obey reasonable instructions given by a manager.
Serious act of insubordination or insulting, abusive or indecent behaviour.
Being under the influence of alcohol or drugs (unless medically prescribed) whilst on duty (note the Trust's Alcohol/Drug Abuse Policy).
Being in possession of illegal substances whilst on the Trust's premises.
Conduct in or outside the workplace which could bring the Trust into disrepute.
Criminal convictions for any offence affecting staff or external relations which amount to a breach of Trust.
Criminal convictions for any offence which affects the individual's ability to carry out their job.
Failure to disclose unspent criminal conviction(s) or any convictions, whether spent or not, in respect of posts exempt under the terms of Rehabilitation of Offenders Act 1975.
Serious breach of Data Protection Act and/or unauthorised disclosure of any Trust information e.g. information about staff, patients, or that is commercially confidential.
Making malicious or unfounded allegations of a serious nature.
Any form of discrimination, harassment, bullying or victimisation.
Long term unauthorised absence (4 weeks or more) or persistent unauthorised absence.
Wilful or reckless breach of any code of conduct, rules or regulations issued by any statutory or regulatory body to which the Trust and/or its Staff are subject.

Corruption – The Trust's Policy on gratuities sets out provisions regarding the acceptance of gifts and hospitality. The conduct of staff in the public service must be scrupulously impartial and honest.

Failure to disclose an interest of self/family/associate in a Contract. Contrary to the Standing Orders of the Trust (this rule is only applicable to Officers specifically involved in this type of work). Advice on the Trust's policy is available on request.
Failing to comply with the Trust's Standing Orders or Standing Financial Instructions.
Loss of legal authority to continue employment.
Loss of professional registration or breach of professional codes of conduct.
Breach of confidentiality.

Misrepresentation – a misrepresentation of details required on application for employment with the Trust with special reference to a failure to disclose conviction as required under the Rehabilitation of Offenders Act 1974 (Exemptions) Order 1975.
Other behaviour that may destroy the relationship of Trust and confidence between employer and member of staff.
This list takes into account the main categories of likely serious offences: the list cannot however be considered exhaustive.

Appendix 3: Suspension / Exclusion Guidance

These rules apply to all staff except medical doctors and dentists where exclusion will be dealt with accordance to the Managing High Professional Standards in the NHS, however, the principles of this policy will apply to Doctors and Dentists in so far as they are not inconsistent with MHPS.

Staff, for whom suspension from duty is considered necessary, will be suspended from duty immediately if this course of action is deemed necessary. Payment for the remainder of the shift being worked will be made on full pay. Whilst suspended, staff must report any sickness and request annual leave, in writing, to their line manager; and must make themselves available for contact and recall to work. Staff will usually be paid their contracted salary whilst on suspension.

All cases of suspension from duty must be confirmed in writing by the appropriate manager as soon as practicably possible, and in any event, within 5 calendar days of the decision being taken. The letter must confirm the reason for the suspension. The confirming letter will state:
The reason for the suspension
The fact it will, in appropriate circumstances, be on full pay and if not why not
The period for which it is anticipated the member of staff will remain suspended
The fact it is a precautionary measure and does not presume guilt or blame.
The terms of the suspension (e.g. not to contact colleagues or anyone who might be a witness, not to enter regular workplace, not to access systems etc.)
The support available from Occupational Health/counselling services if required; and
Who to contact if there are any queries

Staff on suspension will be offered the support of the Occupational Health Department and the Trusts employee assistance programme on a confidential basis. As a point of contact a member of the Employee Relations Team will be identified for the duration of the suspension.

The Commissioning/Case Manager will review a Suspension every 14 calendar days and Exclusions in accordance with MHPS after 4 weeks, to ascertain the current status of the investigation and the predicted future time scale for review. It is the responsibility of the Commissioning/Case Manager to communicate this to the member of staff.

The member of staff is required to be available during what would be their normal working hours, so if they need to request leave (eg. compassionate leave), they must liaise with their line manager in advance. If the member of staff has previously authorised annual leave during the period of suspension, they will not be expected to cancel it. However, they should remind their line manager or supervisor and notify the Investigating Officer. Further annual leave requested during suspension must be authorised by the Line Manager in the normal manner. The investigation itself will continue during the period of annual leave but without the requirement of the suspended member of staff to attend a meeting during that time.

If  the  member  of  staff is  sick  during  their  suspension, the  normal  sickness  absence procedure applies (e.g. phoning in sick, keeping in contact, providing GP certificates when appropriate) as indicated in the Trust's Sickness Policy. The investigation will continue during a period of sickness absence unless otherwise indicated by Occupational Health. When a suspended member of staff is certified as sick, they will be recorded as being on sick leave and will receive pay in accordance with the Trust's Sickness Policy, although the suspension will remain in force.

During any period of suspension, dependant on the allegation/s the suspension may be held to apply to all contracts of employment held by the member of staff with the Trust. This includes ‘bank registration.' Planned bank shifts will be cancelled. The individual who has been suspended must not undertake ‘similar' paid work for another employer during their normal working hours with the Trust – this includes bank or locum work. The Trust reserves the right to inform other employers in similar organisations that the member of staff is currently suspended from duty, so that they are aware of the current situation.

During the suspension, the member of staff is required to co-operate fully with the investigation to attend investigatory interviews and to remain contactable during what would deem to be their working hours. If a member of staff fails to co-operate this may be considered as unauthorised absence and pay may be withheld.
